subject: RE: [junit] Re: How to test private methods in a class.
msgSnippet: ... I find that writing tests helps me a lot thinking about the design, so I m not a fan of switching my design brain off while writing tests. I m not sure why
messageBody:
> Hmm. Sounds like you have your "Designer" hat on. That wasn't
> what I understood to be the context of the question. "How do
> I test a private method" is a question someone wearing their
> "Tester" hat would ask.

I find that writing tests helps me a lot thinking about the design, so I'm
not a fan of switching my design brain off while writing tests. I'm not sure
why you would want to do that.

> Given that context, my mind hasn't
> changed. If the private method is already tested through an
> existing public method then you don't need to do anything. In
> fact, exposing the method and writing an explicit test against it is
> duplication.

Unless the tests of the already existing public method can be simplified in
consequence.

> Does that mean I believe Extract Class and Move Method are
> never used. Of course not! But I don't think they provide a
> solution, per se, to "How do I test a private method" unless
> the context includes "This wasn't developed TDD and I don't have any
> confidence in it."

I'm confused, because TDD is much more a design practice than a testing
practice. Anyway, I don't think I proposed anything as "a solution per se",
but said that it would be one of the first things I'd think about, and that
I very often find that I find a solution I like when I do so.

> Maybe I'm wrong about this, but I tend to view each of the
> refactorings as a mini-pattern: a solution to a problem in a
> context. Each refactoring describes a motivation which
> includes the context. For example, the motivation for Extract
> Class as described in /Refactoring/ is that the class has too
> many responsibilities and has lost cohesion. I don't see
> anything there about using the refactoring to expose private
> methods of the class for testing. Likewise, the motivation
> for Move Method doesn't include not being able to test a
> method because of access restrictions.

A private method that is complex enough to need explicite testing simply is
a hint to a class that has too many responsibilities and has lost cohesion.
A class that has just one responsibility is quite unlikely to be complex,
let alone have complex private methods.

> Maybe Martin Fowler wasn't wearing his Tester hat at the
> time. Maybe he was and wanted to write a book about how to
> produce better designs, not about solving problems with unit
> tests.

If I remember correctly, he put a chapter about Code Smells in the book -
about hints in the code that you should refactor. Well, I think that a
private method that needs explicite testing is such a smell.

> So, third maybe in a row, maybe refactorings shouldn't
> be viewed as ways to solve problems with your the test suite?

If your design is in the way while writing tests, it looks like a design
problem to me. So I don't see why we should exclude refactoring as a viable
solution.

> Or, maybe it would be an interesting topic to write an
> article on -- how to apply refactorings when your focus is testing
> and not design.

I really have problems following this whole notion of "focus on testing" as
something that excludes thinking about design. It's just not the way I work,
I guess.

Cheers, Ilja
